25.text:

ado, please join me

is a really important skill

that's taking place around

the knowledge revolution,

And that's a revolution in

123.text:
such as ourselves, organizations

there's a part of you

this is a process we're engaged

So that's what I call this

As the form of

for making decisions, not

And my question is what

Because basically my passion
for the last 35 years

514.text:
societies get to yes, from

I think about what makes

what I've gradually come

531.text:
to realize is that the

you know, what could be more

540.text:
Because it seems
like we experience

546.text:
but perhaps the most problematic
is the one with ourselves.

549.text:
And this is what I've found
is that perhaps our biggest

553.text:
opponent, the biggest obstacle
to us getting what we want

561.text:
in life and in our

564.text: what we often think it is.

It's not just the other person
across on the other side

571.text:
That person can
be very difficult.

572.text:
Those people can
be very difficult.

574.text:
And I've specialized in

578.text:
But I find that however
difficult that person

580.text:
is, the most difficult
person we have to deal with

583.text:
is-- I have to deal with,
at least-- is right here.

587.text:
We are, in some ways,
our own biggest opponent.

591.text:
That's the person we look at
in the mirror every morning.

594.text:
That's the person who's going
to give us the most trouble.

596.text:
I think it was President
Teddy Roosevelt who once said,

602.text:
if you could give
a kick in the pants

605.text:
to the person who will give

610.text: you would not sit for a month.

We are often our
own worst enemies

because we human beings, for one

622.text:
We tend to react
in ways to do not

628.text:
And so my question is, how

opponent of ours into

644.text:
That's what I think

647.text: of getting to yes with yourself.

How do you turn your own
opponent, yourself as opponent,

654.text:
And what I've found is

661.text:
And it's almost as if
we've been negotiating.

And the way I've tended to

668.text: on the other side of the table.

669.text:
And I realize that
part the problem

671.text: is on this side of the table.

And it's almost as if we've been
negotiating with one arm tied

676.text:
behind our back because
we're negotiating just

680.text:
focused on the external,

when in fact our
biggest opportunity

685.text:
is to start off by influencing

689.text:
And so what I'd like to do

694.text:
from that realization,
I've kind of

696.text:
come to realize that getting

negotiation that

as the first step towards

749.text:

But I'm going to go over

755.text:
are the very same principles

I think of them as the

765.text:
to the process of

769.text:
So the first, and
maybe the foundation,

773.text:
that I've been teaching for
many years around negotiation

776.text:
is the ability
to-- I like to use

779.text:
the metaphor of
going to the balcony.

785.text:
like you're negotiating
up here on a stage.

Part of your mind goes to a

792.text:
overlooking that stage, which
is a place of perspective.

801.text:
It's a place where you can
keep your eyes on the prize,

807.text:
We're often reacting
out of fear.

811.text:
And as the old saying

you will make the best

And we sometimes get brought

823.text:
attacking the other side
sometimes out of anger,

827.text:
or accommodating, giving in,
to the other side out of fear,

834.text:
How many of you, just out of
curiosity, if I ever ask you--

838.text:
I sometimes think of this as the
three A's-- you know, attack,

843.text:
If you said, I have a

how many would say that you

851.text:
I would say you have a
tendency to attack more

856.text:
How many would say you
have a tendency to avoid?

858.text:
OK, and sometimes we use a
combination of all of them.

864.text:
We may accommodate for a
long time with our child,

867.text: and then we suddenly lose it.

869.text:
You've been to that
movie, you know?

871.text:
And then we attack, and
then we go back to avoiding.

876.text:
The question is, is
there a better way?

878.text:
And I think there
is a better way

879.text:
of getting to yes, which
is actually engaging

881.text:
the differences in
a constructive way.

883.text:
But in order to do
that, it requires

885.text: us to go to the balcony.

886.text:
And it's hard to go to
the balcony these days.

892.text:
all our technology and cell
phones and texts and tweets

896.text:
and everything that's going on,
it's so easy to get reactive.

900.text:
I mean, for example, you're
sitting there at your computer

904.text:
and you get an email that you
suddenly felt, wait a minute.

908.text:
They didn't consult
me on that decision.

910.text:
And you kind of feel

So it's just very natural
to compose a reply.

919.text:
But you don't just

921.text: you hit the Reply All button.

923.text:
And then it goes out to
the entire organization

926.text:
and you start to see
conflicts start to escalate.

929.text:
There is a button on that
screen that is often rarely used

932.text:
that I think of as
the balcony button,

934.text: and it says, Save as Draft.

937.text:
That's the one where you
get it out of your system.

939.text: You save it as a draft.

941.text:
Then everyone has their
favorite techniques

944.text:
Some people might, you
know, breathe or meditate.

947.text:
Some people might go for a walk
in these lovely surroundings

951.text:
here or go have a cup of coffee
with a friend or sleep on it.

954.text:
But you're going to come
back after a few minutes

957.text:
You're going to
look at that email

958.text:
and you're going to ask
yourself the important question.

961.text:
Is this going to
advance my interests?

964.text:
Is this really going to serve
the needs of the situation?

967.text:
And most likely you're going
to hit the Delete button,

971.text:
and then you're going to pick up
the phone and call the person,

974.text:
get together with
them or however

975.text: to try to resolve the situation.

977.text:
Because email as it turns
out, while it's a great way

980.text:
to convey information,
is not such a great way

984.text:
to deal with anything
that's emotionally delicate.

987.text:
So those are all ways
of going to the balcony.

992.text:
But the question
is, a lot of people

993.text:
find that they fall
off the balcony.

998.text:
And so the question is how
can we say on the balcony?

1000.text:
And so this brings me
to the next principle,

1004.text:
which is one of the key
principles of negotiation.

1007.text:
I mean, if people ask me,
what's the most important skill

1010.text:
that a negotiator
needs to have-- there

1012.text:
are a lot of skills
that we need to have,

1014.text:
but if I had to pick one--
usually I pick this one.

1016.text:
It's the ability to put yourself
in the other side's shoes,

1020.text:
in other words, the ability
to try and understand

1023.text:
what your coworker really
wants or what your child wants

1027.text:
or what your
significant other wants.

1030.text:
Because after all, negotiation
is an exercise in influence.

1034.text:
You're trying to
change someone's mind.

1036.text:
How can we possibly
change their mind

1039.text:
if we don't know
where their mind is?

1041.text:
So putting yourself
in their shoes is key.

1043.text:
But what I've discovered
in teaching this over many,

1046.text:
many years is that it's
not easy for people

1049.text:
to put themselves in
the other side's shoes.

1052.text:
It's not easy for us to listen
to others because there's

1054.text:
so much going on for
us in our own minds

1057.text:
already that there's no mental
or emotional space for us

1062.text:
to be able to invite in the
other person's concerns.

1066.text:
And so the biggest block to
us being able to put ourselves

1069.text:
in the other side's
shoes-- which is key

1071.text:
if you're dealing with
customers or clients or anything

1073.text:
like that, it's absolutely key--
but the biggest block is us.

1077.text:
And so what I
found paradoxically

1078.text:
is that there is a psychological
antecedent to putting ourselves

1083.text:
in the other person's
shoes, and that's

1085.text:
to put ourselves in
our own shoes first.

1089.text:
In other words, not
just to listen to them,

1092.text:
but before we can
listen to them properly,

1094.text: we need to listen to ourselves.

1097.text:
We need to be able to see
ourselves from the balcony.

1099.text:
We need to be able to practice
the skills of self observation

1106.text:
I think it was Benjamin
Franklin who centuries ago said,

1110.text:
observe all people,
yourself most of all.

1115.text:
So what I'd like to do is
tell you a little story,

1119.text:
just if I may, from
my own experience

1121.text:
of when I began to really focus
on this whole issue of how

1128.text:
I was involved some
years ago as a mediator

1139.text:
I had been asked
by President Carter

1142.text:
to be a third party in between
the government of Venezuela,

1147.text:
the president whose name was
Hugo Chavez-- some of you

1150.text:
may remember him-- and
the political opposition.

And it was a time when there
were about a million people

1157.text:
on the streets of
Caracas, the capital city,

1160.text:
demanding the resignation of the
president and a million people

1165.text:
And there was some
violence, and people

1166.text:
were genuinely afraid it
might lead to a civil war.

1169.text:
Anyway, at one point-- I
had a number of meetings

1172.text:
with President Chavez--
but one of them--

1175.text:
he was a kind of complex and
somewhat volatile individual--

1179.text:
but at one of them, we had
a meeting with my friend

1183.text:
Francisco, colleague
Francisco, set at 9 o'clock.

1185.text:
He liked to meet at night
in the presidential palace.

1190.text:
And finally midnight came
and we were ushered in

1194.text:
Instead of finding
him alone at midnight,

1195.text:
we found his entire
cabinet arrayed behind him.

1199.text: He said, have a seat here.

1201.text:
Now tell me what do you
think of the situation here?

1207.text:
And I said, well, you
know, Mr. President, I've

1209.text:
been talking to some of your
government ministers here

1211.text:
and some of the opposition
and it seems to me

1217.text:
As soon as he heard the word
progress, he got triggered.

1219.text:
He said, what do
you mean progress?

1221.text:
You're not seeing
the dirty tricks

1223.text:
those traitors in the
opposition are up to.

1227.text:
And he proceeded to get furious,
leaned in very close to my face

1231.text:
and started to yell for
approximately 30 minutes,

1237.text: in front of his entire cabinet.

1238.text:
Now if you put yourself in my
shoes, I was kind of going,

1243.text:
You're trying to defend yourself
and thinking about that.

1246.text:
But then, thankfully,
I was able to go

1249.text:
to the balcony for a
moment and ask myself

1253.text:
Is it really going to advance
my cause, the cause of peace,

1256.text:
for me to get into an
argument with the president

1259.text: So I thought the better of it.

1260.text:
I bit my tongue, and I
just listened to him.

1263.text:
And sure enough,
he was a man who

1265.text:
could go on for eight hours,
give a speech, no problem.

1269.text:
If I had interrupted him
and tried to argue with him,

1271.text:
I'm sure it could have
gone way off the tracks.

1275.text:
And I was thinking in
myself, OK, two years of work

1278.text:
here in Venezuela
all down the drain.

1280.text:
You get reactive in
a situation like that

1282.text:
when someone is shouting
at you like that.

1285.text:
But somehow I was able
to go to the balcony,

1290.text:
And I saw after 30 minutes,
by me not reacting,

1295.text:
I saw his shoulders kind
of sink a little bit.

1298.text:
And in a weary tone of
voice he said to me finally,

1301.text: so, Bill, what should I do?

1305.text:
Well, that is the sound
of a human mind opening.

1309.text:
When you try to deal
with someone who's

1311.text:
in an angry state
of mind, they're

1313.text: not going to listen to reason.

1315.text:
But at some point he
finally is saying, OK, so

1319.text:
He's willing to open, so
I said, Mr. president,

1321.text:
I think the entire
country of Venezuela

1323.text: needs to go to the balcony.

1330.text:
Why not have a truce
and give everyone

1333.text:
a chance to enjoy the
holidays with their families?

1335.text:
And when we come
back in January,

1337.text:
maybe everyone will
be in a better mood.

1340.text:
And President Chavez
said, that's a great idea.

1342.text:
I'm going to propose
that in my next speech.

1346.text:
And then he said
to me, you know,

1348.text:
over Christmas I'm going to
travel around the country.

1350.text:
And I'd like you to come
with me and see the country.

1353.text:
